messageBody:
So - what I'm having trouble cost justifying is introducing a
> runtime influencing technology that simply is a stylistic
> programming change - from "test" to "@Test". There is no value-add
> here. Right? No additional value to customers and no additional
> value to developers. It is simply style.
>
> Or, am I fundamentally missing something.


I don't know about fundamentally missing something. But some small added
value comes from being able to derive my test case from any class (including
Object). On some rare occasions its been helpful to derive my test case from
the Object under test (BTW I've only done this with NUnit in .NET land).

In addition assuming the test runners are like those in NUnit/MbUnit it
would be possible to write a new test runner that accepted tests
dynamically. With some integration testing we did on a .NET project I used
this feature (it was fully baked into MbUnit) to create a test per query
file. The tests ran the query, exported the output and then compared the
results to a previously saved set of results. This allowed QA to extend the
regression testing as they tested new features or bugs - without any
intervention from the development team.
